docs.lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of last night's Presidential debate in Hartford, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service. The moderator was Jim Lehrer of PBS. MODERATOR The order for everything tonight was determined by coin toss. Now, to the opening statements and to President Clinton. Mr. President. CLINTON Thank you, Jim. And thank you to the people of Hartford, our hosts. I want to begin by saying again how much I respect Senator Dole and his record of public service, and how hard I will try to make this campaign and this debate one of ideas, not insults.

headline.main: A Transcript of the First Televised Debate Between Clinton and Dole

docs.abstract: Transcript of Presidential debate in Hartford, Conn, between President Clinton and Bob Dole as transcribed by Federal Document Clearing House (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: We note that some of the data in the Journal of the American Medical Association study that you cite in your Oct. 2 news article ''Elderly and Poor Do Worse Under H.M.O. Plans' Care'' are 10 years old.

docs.lead_paragraph: AS National Mental Illness Awareness Week opens, attention is being focused on new ways of treating depression, and returning its victims to functioning lives. ''Am I just experiencing blues that will pass?'' is the question posed by Dr. Sheila A. Cooperman, a staff psychiatrist at Silver Hill Hospital in New Canaan. It will be answered at a free screening on Thursday in a local church. ''The good news,'' Dr. Cooperman said, ''is that research and case histories reveal 60 to 70 percent do recover using a combination of treatments.''

headline.main: Help for Depression Put in the Foreground

docs.abstract: Silver Hill Hospital, New Canaan, Conn, to offer free screening for depression at local church as part of National Mental Illness Awareness Week; Dr Sheila A Cooperman and former hospital patients comment on treating depression (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: 2BR, HI FLR, AC, OVRSZ WNDWS, SPECTAC RV VU, INDOR PRKNG, HLTH CLB, TENNIS, ADJ TO PARK, 5 MIN TO GRND CENTRL. $25,000. NO, that's not a misprint: $25,000, give or take a few thousand, will be the asking price for the well-appointed two-bedroom apartments going on sale this December in a mixed residential-commercial development inspired by Battery Park City. Smaller apartments in this unsubsidized 42-story co-op will go for much less -- under $10,000 for a studio lacking a gonzo view of the East River. What's the catch? One risk for buyers is that if Queens West doesn't take off they may be stuck with apartments they cannot sell. The site, a largely abandoned industrial swath of the Hunters Point neighborhood of Queens directly opposite the United Nations, is plainly a reach for prospective buyers accustomed to a Starbucks on every corner. And the commercial developers -- a group headed by the Mellon Bank Corporation -- want to break through qualms about living in Queens West by transferring much of the initial risk of ownership from co-op purchasers to the Federal Housing Administration.
docs.abstract: Article on new Queens West co-op in Hunters Point neighborhood of Queens; $25,000 will be asking price for two-bedroom apartments going on sale this Dec in mixed residential-commercial development inspired by Battery Park City; apartment buyers will own their own homes after their first payment, but will be responsible for paying down building's mortgage as part of their monthly maintenance; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If the catch phrase that emerged from the Republican sweep in the 1994 elections was ''angry white men,'' then what will it be this election season? ''Anxious white women,'' suggested Karen Hasse Ball, a mother of two who lives with her husband, children, dog and two cats on a leafy street in this Los Angeles suburb and casts her vote based on concerns about her children's future.

headline.main: Suburbs' Soccer Moms, Fleeing the G.O.P., Are Much Sought
headline.kicker: POLITICS -- Political Battle of the Sexes Is Tougher Than Ever

docs.abstract: Early polls show that white suburban women are breaking with their traditional Republican leanings and spurning Bob Dole in striking numbers; they have become central focus of campaigners and pollsters who consider them part of swing vote, without which Dole cannot win Presidency; latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, conducted in early Sept, found that support for Pres Clinton amoung married white suburban women appears to have jumped dramatically since 1992 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH a vigorous nudge from the American Medical Association, the world's biggest cruise lines agreed last month on standards for medical personnel and facilities aboard ship. While many vessels already meet these levels, cruise line officials agree that there will be a lag before all ships do. But lines that regularly sail to the United States are expected to conform within two years. At present, no international rules require even that a doctor or nurse be aboard or that quarters for treatment be provided, although many cruise ships have doctors and infirmaries.
docs.abstract: Practical Traveler column on medical care aboard cruise ships; explains model guidelines proposed by International Council of Cruise Lines (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers reported last week that elderly people and poor people who are chronically ill fare worse in health maintenance organizations than they do in conventional insurance plans. But the findings seem unlikely to slow the remarkable growth of H.M.O. enrollment. The researchers said medical outcomes were not much different for average patients in H.M.O.'s and in fee-for-service insurance plans. But, they said, ''Patients who were elderly and poor were more than twice as likely to decline in health in an H.M.O.'' than in a fee-for-service plan.

headline.main: Elderly and Poor Suffer Under H.M.O. Plans

docs.abstract: Study finding that chronically ill elderly and poor people do worse under HMO care than under conventional insurance plans noted (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In nearly four years as President, Bill Clinton has made thousands of speeches: short ones, long ones, big ones, little ones, good ones, bad ones. But in a way, he has made just one speech -- over and over and over again. To be sure, the words change, and so do the ideas. Four years ago, Mr. Clinton spoke of providing health insurance to all Americans and expanding education and training to equip workers for a global economy. Now he talks of 48-hour hospital stays for mothers and newborns and uniforms for schoolchildren.

headline.main: Clintonian Speeches: A Guide for Listeners

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton's speeches over the last four years have differed in size, focus and details, but they follow certain patterns closely enough to allow construction of a listener's guide and gazetteer to the spaces and places he visits when he speaks (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Wellpoint Health Networks Inc. may be buying the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company's health insurance business as part of an expansion that could include more acquisitions. People familiar with the situation said that Wellpoint, a managed-health-care company, was close to buying the unit. The price was not disclosed. The Hancock unit, which earned less than $10 million last year and has more than 3,000 employees, would be a good acquisition if the price was relatively low, said Paul Goulekas of Conning & Company.

headline.main: WELLPOINT MAY BUY JOHN HANCOCK'S HEALTH UNIT

docs.abstract: Wellpoint Health Networks Inc may be buying John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co's health insurance business as part of expansion that could include more acquisitions; price not disclosed (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Eastman Kodak Company and Wang Laboratories announced yesterday that Kodak was in negotiations to buy Wang's document imaging software business. The sale would bring Wang closer to its stated goal of becoming a services-only company. And it would give Kodak a potential replacement product for its flagging microfilm and microfiche business.

headline.main: Kodak in Talks to Buy a Wang Software Unit

docs.abstract: Eastman Kodak Co and Wang Laboratories announce that Kodak is in negotiations to buy Wang's document imaging software business; sale would bring Wang closer to its stated goal of becoming services-only company; it would give Kodak potential replacement product for its flagging microfilm and microfiche business; analysts say Kodak would pay between $300 million and $400 million for the Wang unit (M)
